contentrichtext.text: {{other uses2|Faulkner}} The '''PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction''' is awarded annually by the [[PEN/Faulkner Foundation]] to the authors of the year's best works of fiction by living American citizens.<ref name=PEN>{{cite web|title=Award for Fiction|url=http://www.penfaulkner.org/award_for_fiction|publisher=PEN/Faulkner Foundation|accessdate=21 July 2011}}</ref> The winner receives US $15,000 and each of four runners-up receives US $5000. Finalists read from their works at the presentation ceremony in the Great Hall of the [[Folger Shakespeare Library]] in [[Washington, D.C.]]. The organization claims it to be "the largest peer-juried award in the country."<ref name=PEN/> The award was first given in 1981.<ref name=krebs>{{cite web |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1981/04/18/nyregion/notes-on-people-new-york-writer-getting-pen-faulkner-award.html |title=Notes on People; New York Writer Getting PEN/Faulkner Award |date=April 18, 2981 |accessdate=August 29, 2012 |work=New York Times |author=Albin Krebs and Robert Thomas}}</ref> The PEN/Faulkner Foundation is an outgrowth of [[William Faulkner|William Faulkner's]] generosity in using his 1949 [[Nobel Prize]] winnings to create the William Faulkner Foundation; among the charitable goals of the foundation was "to establish a fund to support and encourage new fiction writers." The foundation's first award for a "notable first novel," called the William Faulkner Foundation Award, was granted to [[John Knowles]]'s [[A Separate Peace]] in 1961. [[Mary Lee Settle]] was one of the founders of the PEN/Faulkner award after controversy at the 1979 [[National Book Award]], when PEN voted a boycott on the ground that they were too commercial.<ref name=krebs/><ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2005/09/28/AR2005092802519.html?nav=rss_metro/obituaries| title=Novelist Mary Lee Settle; Founded PEN/Faulkner Award| author=Matt Schudel| work=Washington Post | date=September 29, 2005 }}</ref> It is affiliated with the writers' organization [[International PEN]]. The award is [[List of PEN literary awards|one of many PEN awards]] sponsored by [[International PEN]] affiliates in over [[International PEN centres|145 PEN centres]] around the world. ==Award winners== *1981 - [[Walter Abish]], ''[[How German Is It]]'' *1982 - [[David Bradley (novelist)|David Bradley]], ''[[The Chaneysville Incident]]'' *1983 - [[Toby Olson]], ''[[Seaview (novel)|Seaview]]'' *1984 - [[John Edgar Wideman]], ''[[Sent for You Yesterday]]'' *1985 - [[Tobias Wolff]], ''[[The Barracks Thief]]'' *1986 - [[Peter Matthew Hillsman Taylor|Peter Taylor]], ''The Old Forest'' *1987 - [[Richard Wiley]], ''[[Soldiers in Hiding (novel)|Soldiers in Hiding]]'' *1988 - [[T.
